author: msftrncs
body:
The following definition of `TokenKind.Generic` would indicate that all tokens of `TokenKind.Generic` should be a `StringToken`. (or specifically either StringLiteral or StringExpandable)

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/22c6fb4a8753ec2d78b2fb1720e73366805c5e6f/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/parser/token.cs#L65-L72

However, the method `Token.SetIsCommandArgument` does not guarantee that.  This method is used to revert the `TokenKind` of special tokens when they appear as command names or arguments.  Most all the special tokens that receive this treatment are not `StringToken`s.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/22c6fb4a8753ec2d78b2fb1720e73366805c5e6f/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/parser/token.cs#L1200-L1208

Should the documentation above `TokenKind.Generic` be reworded?

Reference PR #10295.
title: Are all TokenKind.Generic tokens actually StringToken?
